intro: Acanthophyllum glaucum, commonly known as the woolly acanthophyllum, is a perennial shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its dense, silver-gray foliage covered in fine, woolly hairs, which help reduce water loss in harsh environments. The plant produces small, inconspicuous yellow flowers during the summer months. It is well adapted to sandy soils and can survive in extreme temperatures. Due to its resilience, it plays an important ecological role in stabilizing desert ecosystems.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthophyllum glaucum is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of central Asia, particularly in countries such as Kazakhstan, Mongolia, and parts of China. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is commonly found in desert steppes and dunes. This plant is well adapted to harsh environmental conditions, including extreme temperatures and limited water availability. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for small desert fauna. Its distribution is closely linked to the specific climatic and geological features of its native range.
